p: Evidence, to date, indicates that the spectral tuning of M/LWS pigments (499 nm to 571 nm) ( 4), measured by the wavelength of maximum sensitivity (λ max), is mainly controlled by amino acid identity at five critical sites (positions 180, 197, 277, 285, and 308) ( 5), although other sites (e.g., 213 and 294) may also affect spectral tuning via epistatic interactions ( 6). Predicted λ max values from known critical sites imply spectral shifts in M/LWS pigments during the diversification of mammals ( 7), yet these have rarely been validated ( 5), and their ecological significance is not known.
